concept.title: Content Addressing Systems
concept.shortdesc: Humans use an infinite number of different modes of addressing from sentimental to scientific. My art project looks at various forms of addressing, including the Interplanetary File System (IPFS). IPFS uses content addressing to identify and locate content.

section.title: Addressing Protocols and Standards
section.p:
Addressing protocols and standards make things findable. In real-life, humans are more than capable of understanding multiple addressing schemes. For example, the average probably is able to use the following systems to find a location, object, or information.
Street addresses
Landmarks
Dewey decimal system
Longitude and latitude

The web uses a combination of protocols and standards such as CID/HTTP/TCP-IP/W3C/ARP. Together, these addressing protocols determine how assets and resources are addressed, stored and retrieved on the web.

section.title: Content Addressing
section.p: When you take any digital asset, say an image, and process it with a cryptographic hash, or function, the result is a unique series of numbers and letters for this exact image.

This result is a content address ID (CID). These CIDs that result from cryptographic hash are a form of the image's address. as a location address.
If I share the following link, it lives in multiple places on the web but all of the following links are guaranteed to be the exact same, unaltered image.

As this is a globally unique ID, if I request this image, can be retrieved from any number of servers. Its authenticity can be easily verified by running the image through a hash and verifying that it is indeed the same image.
Another way to look at CIDs is to consider them as a text-based and unique property of the content object.
If you've published a book and have a different version of the book, its CID will change. In that case, you can create specific links to the original version of the book as well as version two.
